title: 15 best snow blowers, snow throwers for winter 2024 in Canada
text:
Yahoo Canada is committed to finding you the best products at the best prices. We may receive a share from purchases made via links on this page. Pricing and availability are subject to change. Yahoo Canada Style 15 best snow blowers & snow throwers for winter 2024, according to reviewers Should you buy a snow blower or a snow thrower? Here's what to know. Read full article Kayla Kuefler Â· Shopping & Lifestyle Editor January 12, 2024 at 7:02 p.m. Best snow blowers and throwers of 2024, according to reviewers (Photo via Getty)
If this winter has felt warmer than usual, you have El NiÃ±o to thank. El NiÃ±o, a climate pattern marked by above-average sea surface temperatures, has delayed consistent cold conditions for many Canadians, postponing the season's snow, ice and frost. However, some climate scientists forewarn a "dramatic pattern change" in January and February, bringing blizzard-like conditions back to several provinces. Environment Canada has issued an extreme cold warning for all of Alberta, and in eastern Canada, one weather system is expected to bring 20 to 40 centimetres of snow. Though the season's snowfall can be challenging to predict, the white stuff will eventually find its way, prompting the need for a new snow blower or thrower.
Snow blower vs. snow thrower: What's the difference? While they essentially perform the same task, snow blowers and snow throwers are, in fact, two different things.
A snow thrower is a single-stage machine, meaning it uses a rotating auger to pick up snow and cast it out of the shoot in one continuous motion.
A snow blower, on the other hand, works in two stages. Similar to a snow thrower, it uses a rotating auger to scoop up snow, but rather than immediately shooting it out, it feeds the snow into an impeller (a powerful fan) which blows it out of the chute.
Snow blowers versus snow throwers: What's the difference? (Photo via Getty) Do I need a snow blower or a snow thrower? There are a few factors to consider to determine whether you need a snow blower or a snow thrower.
Snow conditions : If you don't typically get a lot of snow, a snow thrower may be a better option as they're smaller and less powerful than a snow blower, which means they tend to be less expensive. If you're used to seeing heavy snow conditions, you'll be better off with a snow blower as they're larger, more powerful and equipped to handle heavy snowfall.
Gas-powered vs. electric: Many snow throwers are corded, meaning you can rely on your home's electricity for power. However, that also means you have limitations on how long the cord is and where you can take your machine. On the other hand, snow blowers tend to be fuel-powered, so you have flexibility on where you can take them, but in turn, they require gasoline and more maintenance than their electrical counterparts.

If you're interested in investing in a snow blower or snow thrower this winter season, scroll down to shop 15 reviewer-loved-and-tested snow blowers and throwers under $500, $1,000 and $2,000.

Backed by a 4.6-star rating, Canadian Tire shoppers promise it's "extremely easy to use" and say the snowblower makes them the "envy of [their] neighbours."

A steal at less than $250, this affordable snow thrower is an ideal size for small to mid-sized driveways and walkways. Its powerful 13-amp motor can move up to 550 lbs of snow per minute and its 180-degree adjustable directional chute can throw snow up to 20 ft.

With a powerful 15A motor, this affordable machine moves up to 25 tons/hr. of snow, features a 180-degree adjustable directional chute and has dual 3W LED headlamps to brighten the way during nights and early mornings.

It's ideal for quick snow removal on mid-sized driveways and walkways and comes backed by a 4.1-star rating from Amazon shoppers. This snowblower is "amazingly good!" writes one reviewer. "It has done a great job for us all winter, they say. "I wouldn't hesitate to buy it again."

It's "well worth the price."

Ego Power's cordless electric two-stage snowblower offers the power of a gas snowblower without the noise, fuss or fumes. It's built with two EGO 56V ARC Lithium batteries to tackle nasty snow conditions and with a 24" clearing width and 20" intake height, it can handle even the deepest snow.

With a promising average rating of 4.6 stars, this Briggs & Stratton snow blower is a unit worth investing in, according to Canadian Tire reviewers. The two-stage snowblower is powered by a 208 cc Snow Series engine and has a push-button electric start for quick and easy starting down to -28.8Â° C. "[You] can't beat Briggs & Stratton," writes one shopper. "I couldn't believe how handy the power steering is," they add.

Banks at the end of the driveway were a breeze," and added, "This is my third snowblower and I'm kicking myself for not buying this the first time."
